## Task 1
a) Store the data below in a data frame object named `my_df`.


|Person | Preference|
|:------|:----------|
|Alice | Twitter |
| Bob | Facebook |
| Charlie | Twitter |
| Denise | Instagram |
| Erin | Facebook |
| Frank | Twitter |
| Gisele | Twitter |
| Harry | Instagram |


```{r}
my_df <- data.frame(Person=c('Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie', 'Denise', 'Erin', 'Frank', 'Gisele', 'Harry'), Preference=c('Twitter', 'Facebook', 'Twitter', 'Instagram', 'Facebook', 'Twitter', 'Twitter', 'Instagram'))
my_df

```

b) What are the dimensions of `my_df`?
8 columns by 2 rows
```{r}
dim(my_df)
```
c) Write R code that counts the total number of users.
```{r}
nrow(my_df)
```
d) Write R code that counts the total number of users who prefer Twitter.

```{r}
nrow(subset(my_df,Preference=='Twitter'))

```
e) Write R code that returns what Gisele prefers.

```{r}
my_df[7,'Preference']
```

## Task 2
a) Create a vector named `my_vec` that includes all integers from 1 to 10 (inclusive).
```{r}
my_vec <- c(1:99)
for (word in my_vec){
  print(word)
}
```

b) Replace the second element in `my_vec` with the number `99`.

c) Write a function called `my_func` that prints `This element is greater than 5!` if an element in `myvec` is greater than 5, and `This element is NOT greater than 5!` otherwise.

```{r}
my_func <- function(number){
if(number <5){
   print('This element is NOT greater than 5!')
} else if(number>5){
  print('This element is greater than 5!')
} else if(number == 5){
  print('your number is 5!')
}
}
my_func(length(my_vec))
```


## Task 3
a. Write a function named `get_fibonacci` that returns the n'th value in the [fibonacci sequence](https://www.cuemath.com/numbers/fibonacci-sequence). For example, `get_fibonacci(5)` should return 5; `get_fibonacci(7)` should return 13 and so on. ***Hint:** It is possible to call the same function from inside it. E.g., you can call `get_fibonacci()` from inside `get_fibonacci()`. Like the movie inception!*

```{r}

 get_fibonacci<- function(number){
if(number <=1){
   return (number)
 } else if(number>1){
  return (get_fibonacci(number-1) + get_fibonacci(number-2))
}
 }
get_fibonacci(19)
  
  




```


b. Let's see R's computational power. Using your function in part (a), find and return the 19th value in the fibonacci sequence.
